p: Ethnobotanical studies on vegetables often include wild vegetables. In the present study, we considered “wild vegetables” to be vegetables that were not cultivated but collected from the wild environment. Twenty-eight species are recorded (Table 1). Among them, Dregea volubilis (UR = 230) was the species most frequently seen in the markets, followed by Centella asiatica (UR = 105). These species were also recorded as medicinal plants in the selected herbal books on traditional Myanmar medicine [ 16, 47, 48].
